docs.abstract: The two countries finally swap enclaves held over from another era, but the locals are worried.
docs.snippet: The two countries finally swap enclaves held over from another era, but the locals are worried.
docs.lead_paragraph: COOCH BEHAR, India — It is June 6, a hot afternoon deep in Bengal’s lush farmlands, and people seem to blur before my eyes. There’s a humid haze, but the ground also is shifting beneath our feet. The fields around us are thick with ripening stalks of jute and paddy; the rice dangles in tassels of plump beads. Crops that were sown in Bangladesh will be harvested in India. The peasants who will harvest them are changing nationality even as we speak.

headline.main: Marooned by History in India and Bangladesh

docs.abstract: While the refugees wait for citizenship or resettlement, they are not allowed to work or send their children to government-accredited schools.
docs.snippet: While the refugees wait for citizenship or resettlement, they are not allowed to work or send their children to government-accredited schools.
docs.lead_paragraph: GELUGOR, Malaysia — The more than 3,000 migrants from Bangladesh and Myanmar who recently landed in Indonesia and Malaysia ended weeks of a nightmare at sea only to fall into an administrative limbo that could last years, even decades.

headline.main: Migrants Flooding Into Malaysia and Indonesia Trade One Nightmare for Another
headline.print_headline: Thousands Wait in Southeast Asia, Lost in Time

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

byline.original: By Chris Buckley and Austin Ramzy

docs.abstract: A reporter from The New York Times, aboard a vessel next to the boat with hundreds of Muslims fleeing Myanmar, heard cries of “Please help us!” No country has agreed to take in the migrants.
docs.snippet: A reporter from The New York Times, aboard a vessel next to the boat with hundreds of Muslims fleeing Myanmar, heard cries of “Please help us!” No country has agreed to take in the migrants.
docs.lead_paragraph: IN THE ANDAMAN SEA OFF THAILAND — A wooden fishing boat carrying several hundred desperate migrants from Myanmar was spotted adrift in the Andaman Sea between Thailand and Malaysia on Thursday, part of an exodus in which thousands of people have taken to the sea in recent weeks with no country willing to take them in.

headline.main: Rohingya Migrants From Myanmar, Shunned by Malaysia, Are Spotted Adrift in Andaman Sea
headline.print_headline: Turned Away From Land and Abandoned at Sea

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

byline.original: By Thomas Fuller and Joe Cochrane

docs.abstract: The explosions Saturday morning during a procession in the capital were the third act of violence that an Islamic State account has claimed in Bangladesh in the last month.
docs.snippet: The explosions Saturday morning during a procession in the capital were the third act of violence that an Islamic State account has claimed in Bangladesh in the last month.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Three bombs exploded early Saturday morning during a giant procession here commemorating the Shiite Muslim holiday of Ashura, killing one person, wounding dozens more and unsettling a country that has little history of sectarian tension.

headline.main: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Attack in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: Bombs Target Shiites in Bangladesh on Holy Day

byline.original: By Ellen Barry and Julfikar Ali Manik

docs.abstract: The Mengke Glacier in northwest China is receding fast, and towns along an arid corridor have suffered floods and landslides caused by sudden rainstorms.
docs.snippet: The Mengke Glacier in northwest China is receding fast, and towns along an arid corridor have suffered floods and landslides caused by sudden rainstorms.
docs.lead_paragraph: MENGKE GLACIER, China — Over the years, Qin Xiang and his fellow scientists at a high and lonely research station in the Qilian Mountains of northwest China have tracked the inexorable effects of rising temperatures on one of China’s most important water sources.

headline.main: Chinese Glacier’s Retreat Signals Trouble for Asian Water Supply
headline.print_headline: Chinese Glacier’s Retreat Signals Trouble for Asian Water Supply

docs.abstract: As “hit lists” of secular writers circulate on the Internet, many writers and journalists have become hesitant to publish work that could attract the attention of Islamists.
docs.snippet: As “hit lists” of secular writers circulate on the Internet, many writers and journalists have become hesitant to publish work that could attract the attention of Islamists.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Two businessmen who had published the works of Avijit Roy, a Bangladeshi-American known for his critical writings on religious extremism, were stabbed on Saturday by groups of men in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, the police said. The attack came eight months after Mr. Roy was himself stabbed to death with machetes.

headline.main: 2 Men Who Published Writings Critical of Extremism Are Stabbed in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: 2 Publishers Are Stabbed in Bangladesh as Attacks Rise

byline.original: By Ellen Barry and Julfikar Ali Manik

docs.abstract: Three powerful bombs exploded Friday in two mosques at a naval base in Chittagong during prayer services, the police said.
docs.snippet: Three powerful bombs exploded Friday in two mosques at a naval base in Chittagong during prayer services, the police said.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Three powerful bombs exploded Friday in two mosques inside a naval base in a port city in southern Bangladesh, the police said.

headline.main: Bombs at Bangladeshi Mosques Wound Naval Personnel, Police Say
headline.print_headline: World Briefing | Asia; Bangladesh: Bombs at Naval Base

docs.abstract: If the claim is verified, the killing of Cesare Tavella, 50, would be the Islamic State’s first attack in Bangladesh.
docs.snippet: If the claim is verified, the killing of Cesare Tavella, 50, would be the Islamic State’s first attack in Bangladesh.
docs.lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The Islamic State has claimed responsibility for the shooting death of an Italian aid worker in this city’s diplomatic quarter. If the claim is verified, the killing on Monday night will have been the Islamic State’s first attack in Bangladesh, a country that has been grappling this year with a series of attacks on bloggers who have written critically of Islam.

headline.main: ISIS Says It Killed Italian Aid Worker in Bangladesh
headline.print_headline: ISIS Says It Killed Italian Aid Worker in Bangladesh

docs.abstract: I never feared being treated as an apostate. After the grisly murder of an atheist blogger, now I do.
docs.snippet: I never feared being treated as an apostate. After the grisly murder of an atheist blogger, now I do.
docs.lead_paragraph: Covered in blood, she stands over the body of her husband lying on a sidewalk on the Dhaka University campus. Onlookers, their faces stunned and fearful, circle the protagonists in what looks like a macabre scene from a Bengali jatra, or village opera.

docs.abstract: The victims’ publishing houses had released work by Avijit Roy, a critic of religious extremism who was killed in a similar attack eight months ago.
docs.snippet: The victims’ publishing houses had released work by Avijit Roy, a critic of religious extremism who was killed in a similar attack eight months ago.
docs.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Statements attributed to a regional division of Al Qaeda late on Saturday claimed responsibility for attacks on two publishers in Bangladesh who put out works critical of fundamentalist Islam, according to the SITE Intelligence Group, which monitors radical Islamic propaganda.

headline.main: Al Qaeda Claims Responsibility for Attacks on 2 Publishers in Bangladesh

byline.original: By Ellen Barry and Julfikar Ali Manik
